a). To find out how fast we need go for escape speed use conservation energy equation between Earth's surface ($r=0$)and infinity($ r\rightarrow \infty$). The total mechanical Energy should remain constant throughout motion i-e initial Mechanical enery = Final mechancial enerry . So $$-\frac{G M m}{ R_{earth} } + mV^{2}/2=-\frac{GMm}{\infinty}+mV_{\f}^{2}/2$$ where G - Gravitational Constant , MEarth & MMars their masses respectivly,$V_\text{i}$ Initial Velocity or Escape velosity needed&$ V_\text{F}$Final Veloctiy At Infinity wich shuld b zero as objec reaches infinuty so no more force excerted..so above eqn reduces into $$\Rightarrow -\frac{GMM}{RE}+\frac12 mv^2=0.$$ Solving For v gives us required escpae velocit y$$\sqrt{\frac {2*6.673*(5.98)*10^(24)} {6.37 * 10 ^ 6}}‚âà11km/sec.$$. (a) The kinetic energy T can be expressed using Cartesian or Polar Coordinates; we choose to use Polars here because it will simplify our calculations later on when dealing with Central Forces & Angular Momentum Conservation properties etc.: $$T=\dfrac {1}{2} m\left(\dot r ^2+r^{2}\dot{\theta}^2\right)$$The potential V depends only upon distance from origin hence most conveniently given w/respect to radial coordinate "r" : thus,$V=-\int F\, dr= -\displaystyle\int_{-}(- k / \, r^{\, 2}+ \; k'/\,\, r^{\,\; 3})\,dr =\small{+}\;\!{(k\; /\;\; r)}+{(-}\, {\scriptstyle{{k'}\over}}\,{{\scriptscriptstyle 2}}\,{\cdot}\,{\scriptstyle {{1}}}/{\scriptstyle r}^{\,\!{\, 2}}} \;\;+\;{\rm C}$$where ${\rm C}$ denotes arbitrary integration constants which would become zero if we set the Potential Energy equal to Zero at Infinity . Now putting together Kinetic \& Potential Energies gives us sought-after Langrangian L:=$\boldsymbol{T}-\boldsymbol{V}$:$$\mathcal{L}=\underbrace{\dfrac {1}{2} m\left(\dot r ^2+r^{2}\dot{\theta}^2\right)}_{\text{Kinetic Energy}}-\underbrace{(\frac{k}{r}+\frac{-k'/2}{r^2})}_{\text{Potential Energy}}$$(Note how combining these two expressions neatly yields a term similar to the Linear Harmonic Oscillator but modified due to additional $-k'\cdot\!\big(\!\tfrac{1}{{2}}\,\cdot\,\tfrac{1}{{r}^{2}}\big)$ component.)Now onto next parts:(b)$\textbf{Deriving Equations Of Motion via Euler‚ÄìLagrange Equation}:\;\frac{d}{dt}\!\bigg(\!\frac{\partial \;\mathcal{L}}{\partial \dot q}\bigg)-\frac{\partial \,\mathcal{L}}{\partial q}=0.\quad\text{For }q=r,\,\theta.$Thus applying E-L Eqns to each generalized coordinate $r\,,\theta$: $$\begin{aligned}\frac{d}{dt}(m\dot{r})-m r\dot{\theta}^2 +\frac{k}{r}-\frac{k'}{r^2}&=0 \\\\\frac{d}{dt}(mr^2\dot{\theta})&=0\end{aligned}.$$From second line above , directly follows conservation of Angular Momentum${\mathbf L}:=m\,{\mathbf r}\times{\mathbf v}=m\,({\mathbf i}\,r\cos\theta+{\mathbf j}\,r\sin\theta)\times({\mathbf i}\,\dot r\cos\theta+{\mathbf j}\,\dot r\sin\theta+{\mathbf k}\,\dot\theta)=m\,r^2\dot\theta\,{\mathbf k}$, so indeed d$/$dt($mr¬≤\dotŒ∏$)‚Äâ$=0$; thence Constant Orbital Angular Momenta:$ l := mr^{2}\dot{\theta}$.Next differentiating first Line wrt time gives Newton‚Äôs Second Law For Radial Coordinate:# $(m\ddot{r}-mr\dot{\theta}^2)+\frac{k}{r}-\frac{k'}{r^2}=0.(Eq.\,I)$.This may also be written as${m\ddot{r}}-F_r={-\nabla V}.\qquad (*)$, where Force components ${F_{r},\;F_{\theta}}=-\nabla V=\,(-dV/dr,-dV/(rd\theta))$ respectivelyInPolar Plane, since conservative forces act along radius vector & its perpendicular direction solely then clearly must depend only upon "$r$" ; leaving Perpendicular Component ($F_\theta:=\epsilon=-dV/(rd\theta)$) identically vanishing--in accordance wit established constancy o fAngular mo ment um !Moving On,(C):Assume nowthat $\,l^{2}> - mk'$and findtheequationfororbiti.. In other words assuming condition such taht centrifugalifugalTerm Outweigh Gravitational Attraction Term Then solve aforementionedEqn Ito obtain closed form soln forequationof conic sectionrepresenting trajectory::To do thistake dot product ot both sideswith $(-rsinŒ∏,rcosŒ∏)$ --yielding:-$(\dot{r}√ómsinŒ∏ √ó\dot Œ∏ cosŒ∏‚àí\dot{r}cosmŒ∏ √ó Àô sinŒ∏ )+(ksinŒ∏)/r=( ks‚Ä≤ nŒ∏)/( rs )$.Simplifyusingtrig identities& rearrange following way$-({mdot rdott heta)(sin theta cos theta)+((M*R doubleDot)*SinThetaCosTheta)+(KSIntheta)/r =( KSprime nthtasthrees R ).Subsequently integrate RHS after multiplying num den by Rsuch t hat partial diff w.r.t R vanishes yieldingconstanIntegrating once more overtime leads To desired result :-[math]r[/ma

Answer:(Part A): To show that ($ c{\bf k},\omega$) forms a four vector we need only demonstrate invariance under change of inertial frame according our definition above; i..e., if ($\tilde{{\bf r}},\tilde{{ct}}$) denotes primed coordinates when measured in another reference system moving with constant relative speed v along their common x axis then \[(\tilde {ck})_i=\Lambda_{ij}(ck)_j\]and\[\tilde {\omega}=\Lambda _{0\alpha}\omega^\alpha.\]Now consider special relativity tells us\[t' = \gamma \left( t - \frac{vx}{c^2} \right), \, x' = \gamma (x - vt)\]where as usual \(\displaystyle \gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}.\)Then,\[{\bf k}'=R({\bf n}')=-\nabla_{{\bf x}'}(\phi')=-[\nabla_{\gamma({{\bf x}}-vt)} (\phi)] =\gamma R({\bf n}-v\hat{x})=(I+\frac{(v/c)\beta}{(1+(\beta\cdot{\bf k}/c)^2)^{3/2}}({\bf I}-\beta\beta^T)){\bf K}\]Where ${\bf N}$ points radially outward so it has no z component thus $({\bf I}-{\boldsymbol{\beta}}{\boldsymbol{\beta}}^T){\bf K}={\bf J}$. Here we have $$\gamma=\frac {1}{\sqrt{(1-(u_S / c)^2)}}.$$The relative velocity u S has been given above ($=$$$-vc$) so now $\ gammma =\ frac {$I} {\ sqrt {(i -( -. vc ^ I))}} \\Rightarrow gamma &={\dfrac {l}{V_{light}\cdot T}}= ?.$ Solving further gives us :$\cos^{-1}(‚àíŒ≤)=\cosh^{‚àí1}(\tfrac{1+Œ≥¬≤ŒΩ‚ÇÅŒΩ‚ÇÇ}{‚àö[(1 + Œ≥¬≤)(1 + ŒΩ‚ÇÅ¬≤)][‚àö(1 + ŒΩ‚ÇÇ¬≤)]})=$or equivalently,$T'=Œì‚àóœÑ$,where Œì (= Lorentz factor )is definedby:$Gamma := Gamma _{(v)}:=frac{1}{sqrt{1-{left({frac{v}{c}}right)}^{2}}}equiv {frac{1}{{sqrt {1 - beta ^{2}}}}};$with corresponding inverse transformationrelatingto observationtime œÑ'(in the primed system) back to coordinate time t (unprimed system): ${displaystyle tau =Gamma ,(t-beta ,cx),}$and${displaystyle x=Gamma ,(x'-beta ,ct'),}$.Now substituting values into equation yields :-Time dilation:-As per Time Dilation theory "moving clocks run slow" hence if you were able to observe someone traveling at relativistic speeds they would age slower than those who remained stationary behind."In other words", because \(\Delta{}t'=\gamma\,\Delta{}t\), then \begin{align*} \Delta{}t'&= \gamma\, \Delta{}t\\&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}\times\Delta{}t.\\&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.8C)^2}}{C}}\times3√ó10^5sec\\ &=\frac{{1}}{\sqrt{1-0.64}}\times3√ó10^5 sec\\&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{0.36}}\times3√ó10^5 s e c\\\Rightarrow \Delta {}t^\prime&={5}/{3}\times3X10^5\;sec\\ &\approx5 X„Äñ10„Äó^5 \;sec.\end{align*}.This means after journey completed his twin brother left behing him approximately five hundred thousand seconds.(answer). b.) To derive the equation of motions, we first need to set up Newton's second law $F = ma$. The inverse-cube central force can be written mathematically as  $$ F(r) =-k/ r^3,$$ where k >0 (for attraction), or < 0 if it were repulsive). Here $\mathbf{r}$ denotes position vector with magnitude $|\textbf {r}| \equiv \,$the orbital radius$\,= r$, so that $-d\mathbf{r}/dt=\boldsymbol{\dot{r}}=\mathbf{v}$, velocity; also $\|\boldsymbol{\dot{r}}\|= v\,=\,|\mathbf{v}|$ . Thus $$\frac{-kd\mathbf{r}}{dr} =\text{(mass)} \,\cdot\,\frac{ d(\mathbf{v}^2)}{ dt}.$$Letting m denote mass, this gives us$$\frac {-mk dr}{r^{3}} \;=\;\underbrace{{m}\dfrac{dv^2 }{dt}}_{\large{=2\,m\frac{d}{dt}(v)}}.$$Now integrate both sides w.r.t.$~$ time t using separation of variables method :$$ -\!\int_{r_o}^{r}\!\! {\left({\frac mk }\right)\!\!\left({\frac{1}{r^{\color{red}{3}}}}\right)\!} \!dr\;=\!\int_{{v}_o}^{v}{\!\!\!2\, dv}$$which yields after integration:\begin{align*}& -\frac{{\tfrac km }}{2}\,\left[\frac{1}{r^2}\right]_{r_o}^{r}= [v^2 - {(v_o)^2}] \\ & \;\Rightarrow\;\frac {{\rm v}^2 }{2}+\frac {{ k }}{{r }} =\frac {{\rm v}_{{o}}^2 }{2}+ \!\frac {{ k}}{{r }_{o}}. \end{equation*}. This last result represents conservation of energy, showing that total mechanical energy E$=T+V=$ constant along trajectory,\[E:= \frac{{\bf p}^{\,2}}{2m} + V(r) ~=~\frac{mv^2}{2}-\frac{k}{r}~=~constant.\]For bound states ($E<0$), closed elliptical orbits will ensue when acted upon my such a force field while hyperbolic trajectories prevail for scattering problems($q>0$) due to either positive or attractive forces between two charged particles acting according to Coulomb‚Äôs Law i..e., potential$\propto$-Zze$^2$/R.(The case,$K=-Ze^2$; corresponds exactlyto electron orbitinga nucleusof charge Ze.). In general ,if angular momentum L about the origin Obeingspecified then polar angle Œ∏ satisfies :(with respecttothe radial line )in terms o f u := 1 /r ,\[{L }^{2}\,u ^{2} =(1+u ^{2})(\alpha -Eu ),\]where Œ± stands fora combination involving only constants displayed above plus conservedangularmomentum squared${\it L}^{2}$.This nonlinear ODE may besolvedby introducingan auxiliary variable ${\sigma}^{2}:= {({E}/{L})^{2}}- ({1}/{L^{2}})$.Then one finds\[{(\sigma + u) }^{2} = \frac {2\alpha }{L^{2}}+2\sigma u,\]and further simplification leads directly into P-polar conic section form\[\frac{1}{r}=\frac{p}{1+\epsilon cos (\theta-\omega)}\]In summary therefore our original problem has been reduced analytically via classical mechanics methods like those found within Goldstein et al.'s text "Classical Mechanics" down to expressingorbitsvia Polar Conics rendered possible through utilization of aforementioned Central Force Laws together with clever applicationsofintegration techniques employed throughout derivation process !

[center]# Physics FAQ entry ####### How do you derive expressions relating different inertial frames?" name="faqsourcetopicslistheaderlink">[Physics Faq](/physicsfaq/) [[Category:Relativity]] By Taylor series expansion,
-->$\def\|#1{|\,|#1|} ## DerivationEditThis section needs more work..-[[Special:WhoCalled/1|||-Please log in to edit this page.]]- Please note that this wiki is intended to help students learn how to solve textbook problems. The Law of Conservation of Energy states that "energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can only change forms." In this case however we have observed something which seems contrary - two sources producing sound waves with no resultant amplitude (and hence lower total Intensity) than when each source was played separately! This apparent violation appears due our misunderstanding about how interference works between coherent wavefronts like those produced from musical instruments such as tuning forks etc.. When multiple waves meet head-on they may destructively interfere resulting into reduced overall Amplitude/Intensity compared individually added up values but without violating any fundamental physical principle here since these phenomena occur because both individual contributions were already present before meeting together i.e., there wasn't creation nor destruction happening just redistribution within space itself!. So while initially 2 times I(one fork playing), after adding another similar sounding object causing destructive interferences => Total < initial value yet still obeying laws governing nature including conservations ones !

The time interval between two successive impinging pulses can now change due to Doppler shift & hence ,the listener observes more than one frequncy From these considerations you should arrive at : f ' = {f * [1 + Œ≤ ] } / [ 1+ Œ≤cosŒ∏] Here Œ∏ refers to angle btw direction of propagation of EM radiation n the line joining target n emitter But since reflection takes place against a plane mirror ; cosŒò= -1 Therefore our equation modifies t0 F'=F{1+Œ≤}/[1‚àíŒ≤} As for observing any discernible interference effects i.e. Beats We require |F'-F| > Œ¥F Otherwise all frequencies get smeared together resulting in noise only Thus using above equations alongw ith simple algebraic manipulations yields Œ¥F=|2FŒ≤|/[(1‚àíŒ≤^2)] Which clearly shows dependency upon both F n Œ≤ In case if beta approaches unity i.e. very close to 1; Denominator tends to zero making difference in those two frequencies approach infinity thereby showing presence of easily detectable Interference pattern Now coming onto second part asking about value required for Beta so that reflected tone appears highest possible Frequency within audio limit Given lowest note has angular frequency W_L ~ 25 radians per sec Highest Note Angular frequency W_H~6307radsec^-1 Using doppler formula again namely WH=[WL*(C+VL)]/[ C-VS] Where VS refered here to VELOCITY OF TARGET And not angular velosity!
